Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 45002
Regional—Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (PATA)
December2011
Support for Pan-Beibu Gulf Economic Cooperation
(Cofinanced by the People’s Republic of China Regional 
Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund)
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS
ADB – Asian Development Bank
ASEAN – Association of Southeast Asian Nations
CAFTA – China–ASEAN Free Trade Area
GMS – Greater Mekong Subregion
PBG – Pan-Beibu Gulf
PRC – People’s Republic of China
RCI – regional cooperation and integration
TA – technical assistance
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION
Type – Regional—Policy and advisory technical assistance (R-PATA)
Targeting classification – General intervention
Sector (subsectors) – Multisector (trade and service, transport management and policies)
Themes(subthemes) – Economic  growth (promoting  economic efficiency and enabling 
business environment), and regional cooperation and integration 
(trade and investments)
Location (impact) – Rural (medium), urban (medium), regional (high)
NOTE
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.
Vice-President S. Groff, Operations 2
Director General K. Gerhaeusser, East Asia Department (EARD)
Director Y. Qian,Officer-in-Charge, Public Management, Financial Sector, and 
Regional Cooperation Division, EARD
Team leader Y. Zhang, Senior Regional Cooperation Specialist, EARD
Team member X. Hu, Regional Cooperation Specialist, OREI
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

1
I. INTRODUCTION
1. The  Pan-Beibu  Gulf (PBG)  economic cooperation  was  launched jointly by  the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB),  member  states  of  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations 
(ASEAN), and the People’s Republic of China (PRC) in 2006.1Since then, ADB has provided 
support to PBG economic cooperation in various forms, including technical assistance (TA)2that
supports the work of the PBG Joint Expert Group.3 This regional policy and advisory TA is 
proposed in response to requests by the governments of the ASEAN countries and the PRC for 
ADB to continue its support for PBGcooperation. Consultations were conducted with the ASEAN 
countries and the PRC on various occasions to determine the impact, outcome, outputs, and 
implementation arrangements for the TA, and in particular during the PBG Joint Expert Group 
meeting held on 1June 2011 in Beihai, the PRC, and the sixth PBG forum held on 18–19 
August 2011 in Nanning, the PRC. Broad agreement was reached on key aspects of the TA, 
and strong support was obtained for its design and implementation. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.4
II. ISSUES
2. ADB's Strategy 20205 highlights regional cooperation and integration (RCI) as one of the 
five core operational areas. In line with this strategy, ADB will increase its support for RCI-
related operations to at least 30% of ADB's total activities by 2020. Both the ASEAN countries 
and the PRC are active participants in various RCI initiatives, including the Greater Mekong 
Subregion (GMS) Economic Cooperation Program and many initiatives under the “ASEAN+X” 
framework.  The  global  financial  crisis  has  affected  the  countries  in  this  region  to  varying 
degrees, and there is a need for them to strengthen regional cooperation for a more integrated 
regional economy.
3.  PBG economic cooperation has been seen as one of the two major pillars of ASEAN–
PRC cooperation, the other pillar being the ADB-coordinated GMS Program. While the GMS 
Program supports cooperation mainly in the continental part of the ASEAN–PRC region, the 
PBG  initiative  is  intended  to  focus  on  cooperation  between  the  PRC’s  southern  coastal 
provinces (including Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, Guangdong Province, and Hainan 
Province) and the oceanic part of ASEAN. Thanks to the mutual efforts of the participating 
countries, PBG economic cooperation has gained stronger momentum and emerged as a new 
and important economic partnership under the framework of ASEAN–PRC cooperation. 
4. ASEAN and  the  PRC signed  a  framework  agreement  on  comprehensive  economic 
cooperation in November 2002, with the key objective to deepen economic links and increase 
                                               
1Begun in 2006, the PBG economic cooperation initially focused on promoting cooperation in the Pan-Beibu Gulf, 
which geographically covers the subregion of the southern coastal provinces of the People's Republic of China 
(PRC), Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and Viet Nam. The first forum on PBG 
economic cooperation was cosponsored by the Government of the PRC and ADB in 2006. Over the years, the PBG 
initiative has expanded to include all the 10 member states of ASEANand the PRC. 
2ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance for Capacity Development for Regional Cooperation in the People’s Republic of 
China and Mongolia. Manila. The project helped establish the PBG Joint Expert Group and supported its work in its 
initial stage. 
3The PBG Joint Expert Group comprises members from all the countries participating in PBG cooperation, including 
senior officials from the ministries of trade and/or economy as well as scholars with special expertise in regional 
cooperation. It was established in July 2008 with a mandate to conduct a feasibility study on PBG economic 
cooperation. 
4The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 13 September2011.
5ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila.

2
intraregional trade and investment by establishing the China–ASEAN Free Trade Area, often 
referred to as CAFTA. This paved the way for the conclusion of the Trade in Goods Agreement
in  November  2004, Trade  in  Services  Agreement in  January  2007, and  the Investment
Agreement in August 2009. CAFTA was formally put into implementation on 1 January 2010. 
This has given rise to one of the largest free trade areas in the world, comprising 11 countries 
with 1.9 billion consumers and a combined gross domestic product of more than $6 trillion. 
CAFTA is certain to result in positive net trade creation for its member countries. The trade 
between ASEAN and the PRC reached $293 billion in 2010, an increase of 37.5% over 2009. In 
the first half of 2011, ASEAN–PRC trade grew by 25.4% to $171 billion. The PRC is now 
ASEAN’s largest trading partner, while ASEAN has become the PRC’s third-largest trading 
partner. 
5. To fully tap the vast potential of cooperation, several challenges need to be overcome. 
First, although ASEAN as a whole has a trade surplus with the PRC, which stood at $16.4 billion 
in 2010, some individual ASEAN countries like Viet Nam and Indonesia have a rising trade 
deficit with the PRC. Since most of the ASEAN countries hold limited foreign exchange reserves, 
the expanding trade deficit has become a barrier to further trade expansion. Second, while 
ASEAN and the PRC are economically complementary, by and large, there exists competition in 
some sectors, particularly in labor-intensive industries. In the aftermath of the global financial 
crisis,  such  competition  is likely to  intensify due to  the rising  protectionism,  particularly  in 
developed countries. Third, the per capita income is still relatively low in most countries in the 
region, and the ASEAN consumer market, though expanding rapidly, is still small. Fourth, some 
ASEAN countries are concerned that the rapid expansion of the PRC’s economic power could 
lead to loss of their competitiveness and market shares in certain sectors. Promoting closer 
cooperation between the PBG countries will help overcomethese challenges. 
6. Progress has been achieved in PBG economic cooperation, particularly in terms of 
stronger  commitment  from  participating countries  and  clearer  direction  for  the  future.  One 
notable achievement was the establishment of the PBG Joint Expert Group and the completion 
of a Feasibility Report on PBG Economic Cooperation, which was endorsed by the ASEAN–
PRC Economic Ministers’ Meeting on 12 August 2011 and welcomed by the leaders of the 
ASEAN countries and the PRC at the 14th ASEAN–China Summit held on 18 November 2011 in 
Bali, Indonesia.
7. The report concludes that PBG cooperation is highly desirable and will help form a new 
growth pole in Asia and the Pacific by promoting intraregional trade, boosting competitiveness of 
the region as a whole, and cushioning the shocks from global crises. It spells out key principles 
for cooperation: (i) development based on equality and mutual benefit; (ii) results orientation; 
(iii) openness  and  transparency;  (iv) market  rules;  (v)  respect  for  territorial  integrity  of 
participating  countries;  and  (vi) respect for  international  laws,  particularly  those  on  marine 
environment  protection.  It  also  sets priority  areas  for  action: (i)  expanding  infrastructure
connectivity beyond the GMS to link the rest of ASEAN with the PRC; (ii) developing ports and 
maritime transport services; (iii) facilitating cross-border trade and investment with a focus on 
developing trade and economic cooperation zones; (iv) strengthening agriculture cooperation,
especially with a  view  to  solving food  security and food  safety issues;  and (v)  promoting 
industrial cooperation and developing regional value chains. The report further indicates the 
need to design and establish proper cooperation mechanisms such as working groups, senior 
officials’ consultations, ministerial meetings, and a secretariat.
8. To achieve greater success, the PBG initiative will need to further delineate its direction 
and  priorities,  particularly  at  the  sector  level,  formulate  action  plans,  mobilize  substantial

3
financial and human resources, and design an effective institutional mechanism. It also needs to 
coordinate with other ongoing subregional cooperation involving ASEAN countries, particularly 
the GMS Program, Brunei Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines East ASEAN Growth 
Area,  Indonesia–Malaysia–Thailand  Growth  Triangle,  and  various  “ASEAN+X” platforms. 
Special attention should be paid to minimizing duplication of efforts and maximizing synergies 
with those RCI programs in the region. 
III. THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
A. Impact and Outcome
9. The impact of the TA will be stronger regional economic cooperation between the PBG 
countriesdeveloped, contributing to an increase of ASEAN–PRC trade. 
10. The TA's outcome will be a well-defined direction, set of priorities, and institutional 
framework for PBG economic cooperation, contributing to full implementation of CAFTA. The TA 
will formulate a road map for PBG economic cooperation that will help the PBG initiative define 
and position itself appropriately in the current architecture of regional cooperation in East and 
Southeast Asia. Efforts will be made to ensure that the road map will be consistent with and 
take into account other actions already agreed and/or being implemented in the PBG member 
countries, including the new GMS Strategic Framework 2012–2022 and the Implementation 
Blueprints  2012–2016  for  Brunei  Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines  East  ASEAN 
Growth Area and Indonesia–Malaysia–Thailand Growth Triangle, which are being prepared with 
ADB assistance. The TA will also help design an institutional framework for PBG economic 
cooperation as called for by the PBG countries in the Feasibility Report on PBG Economic 
Cooperation. Achieving the intended outcome will help PBG countries tackle the challenges 
they face in fully realizing the vast potential forcooperation in the subregion.
11. The impact and outcome will be achieved through the delivery of the following outputs:
(i) a road map for PBG economic cooperation that will define priority actions for 
cooperation in  selected  key  sectors,  list  the  potential  pilot  projects  of  PBG 
economic cooperation, and include a work program for the next 5years;
(ii) recommendations on a PBG institutional framework, including policy dialogue 
and decision-making mechanisms, sector-specific committees, technical working 
groups, and a secretariat, with respective terms of references; 
(iii) greater capacity of PBG countries for deepening regional economic cooperation; 
and 
(iv) policy briefs and/or best practice notes for high-level decision makers based on 
the above outputs.
B. Methodology and Key Activities
12.  The TA will undertake the following activities:
(i) organizing  studies,  consultations, and workshops to  help  the  PBG  countries 
formulate a road map to operationalize the feasibility report on PBG Economic 
Cooperation; 
(ii) organizing  studies to  help design an  overall institutional framework for  PBG 
cooperation—this  includes taking  stock  of  the  experience  and  practices  of 
various  RCI  programs  with  regard  to  institutional  structure,  analyzing the 
common successful factors, and recommending modalities and measures for 
consideration by the PBG countries;

4
(iii) organizing the meetings of the PBG Joint Expert Group, which will serve as the 
senior officials’ forum before a formal institutional framework is set up; 
(iv) organizing  capacity  building  activities  to  support  the  formulation  and 
implementation of the PBG road map, including training workshops and study 
tours on key subjects such as trade and economic zone development;
(v) organizing  public–private  dialogues  and  business  forums  to  address  private 
sector  needs,  increase  awareness  about  public–private  partnerships,  and 
develop such partnershipopportunities in selected key sectors; and 
(vi) organizing workshops for knowledge sharing among PBG countries and with the 
rest of Asia. 
C. Cost and Financing
13.  ADB will provide $900,000 of which, (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the 
People's  Republic  of  China  Regional  Cooperation  and  Poverty  Reduction  Fund  and 
administered by ADB; and (ii) $400,000 will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The governments of the ASEAN countries and 
the PRC will jointly provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff; office space; 
support for training, seminars, and conferences; and other administrative and logistics services. 
The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
D. Implementation Arrangements
14.  About 10 person-months of international and 40 person-months of national consultant 
services will be required to provide advisory and technical services under the TA. The consultants 
and  resource  persons  will  be  specialists  in  development planning  and  regional  cooperation 
strategy formulation; integrated transport, trade, and investment facilitation; private sector and 
business development; and institutional and capacity building. Because the TA will involve varied 
activities, ADB will engage the consultants and resource persons as individuals based on their 
qualifications and experience and in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants
(2010, as amended from time to time). Appendix 3 provides the outline terms of reference for 
consultants and resource persons. Office equipment will be procured in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and will be transferred to the 
implementing agencies upon TA completion. The TA proceeds will be disbursed in line with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook(2010, as amended from time to time).
15.  The TA will be implemented over 23 months from 1 February 2012 to December 2013. 
ADB will be the executing agency. The Public Management, Financial Sector, and Regional 
Cooperation Division of ADB’s East Asia Department will administer and implement the TA in 
collaboration with the Office of Regional Economic Integration and Southeast Asia Department 
internally, and with the ASEAN Secretariat externally. The implementing agencies will be the 
ministries of trade and/or economy in the PBG countries that are represented in the PBG Joint 
Expert Group. The trade and/or economy ministries will be responsible for overall coordination 
with the respective domestic agencies, and will act as the main channel of communication with 
ADB.  Private  sector  entities  in  the  PBG countries,  particularly  the  national  chambers of 
commerce and industry associations in key sectors, will be engaged. Special attention will be 
paid to the potentially adverse impacts of infrastructure development and trade facilitation, 
particularly the risks of communicable disease and human and drug trafficking.
16.  Monitoring of implementation progress, including reporting of cost, time, risk, quality, 
human  resources,  procurement, and  communications,  will  be  carried  out  through  periodic

5
reviews in accordance with the design and monitoring framework, and will be performed by the 
ADB TA project officer and his or her support team, which will include the international and 
national consultants hired under this TA.
17.  The TA outputs, particularly the findings and recommendations from the studies for a
road map and institutional framework of PBG economic cooperation, will be reported to the 
ASEAN–PRC Economic Ministers’ Meeting and disseminated in the ASEAN countries and the 
PRC, and to other developing member countries through workshops, seminars, conferences, 
publications, and the media. Where appropriate, representatives of the secretariats of other 
regional cooperation bodies will be invited to dissemination events. 
IV. THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the People's Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty 
Reduction Fund, and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 
on a grant basis for Support for Pan-Beibu Gulf Economic Cooperation, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

Appendix 3 9
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS
1. Up  to  10  person-months  of  international  and  40  person-months  of  national 
consultant inputs will be needed to realize the objectives of the regional policy and advisory 
technical assistance (TA). The terms of reference are preliminary at this stage and will be 
expanded in consultation with the governments of the participating countries during the 
fact-finding stage. The consultants will report to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) task 
manager(s) for the TA, who will also be responsible for the overall coordination of project 
activities. The reporting requirement for the international consultants will consist of (i) an 
inception report and work schedule within 2 weeks of mobilization; (ii) a draft final report 
2 weeks before the contract ends, for review and comments by ADB and the governments; 
and (iii) a final report in both hard and soft copies, incorporating all comments. 
A. International Consultants (10 person-months)
1. Regional Cooperation Expert andTeam Leader (6 person-months)
2. The team leader will be a regional cooperation expert with at least a master's 
degree, but preferably a PhD in economics and at least 10 years of experience in regional 
cooperation and macroeconomic development work; and should have extensive experience 
in Asia, particularly with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC). The expert will work closely with the Joint Expert Group 
for Pan-Beibu Gulf (PBG) economic cooperation, the institutional development and capacity 
building  expert,  and  national  consultants  to  develop  a road map  on  PBG  economic 
cooperation. The specific responsibilities will include:
(i) analyzing economic development trends in the PBG countries (ASEAN plus 
the PRC) and consulting extensively with the PBG Joint Expert Group, the 
private  sector,  development  partners,  and  other  major  stakeholders  to 
pinpoint potential economic and regional cooperation opportunities among 
and between the countries;
(ii) reviewing other subregional economic and regional cooperation mechanisms,
and  consolidating  lessons  learned  that  could  help  the  PBG  initiative 
recognizechallenges in its formative stage;
(iii) coordinating,  through  dialogue,  roundtable  consultations,  workshops, and
seminars, the formulation of a road map for PBG economic cooperation,
which should (a) define the priority areas for cooperation, (b) list potential 
pilot projects that will  showcase the unique advantage of PBG economic 
cooperation, (c) include a general work program for the next 5 years, and
(d) recommend an institutional framework for PBG economic cooperation;
(iv) finalizing  the  road map  for  presentation  to  the  ASEAN–PRC  Economic 
Ministers’ Meeting; and 
(v) preparing  policy  briefs  and/or  best  practice  notes  for  high-level  decision 
makers in PBG countries that will also incorporate the recommendations from 
the institutional developmentand capacity building specialist. 
2. Institutional Development and Capacity Building Specialist 
(4 person-months)
3. The expert will have at least 10 years of experience as an institutionaldevelopment 
and capacity building expert, and should have extensive knowledge on the institutional set-

10 Appendix 3
up  of  subregional  economic  cooperation  programs  in  Asia—ASEAN,  Greater  Mekong 
Subregion, Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation, Brunei Darussalam–Indonesia–
Malaysia–Philippines East ASEAN Growth Area. Working closely with the team leader, the 
PBG Joint Expert Group, national consultants, and other major stakeholders, the expert will 
recommend an appropriate institutional framework for  PBG economic cooperation and 
develop a capacity building program for PBG countries as inputs to the road map. The 
specific responsibilities will include:
(i) reviewing the organizational set-up of subregional groupings relevant to PBG 
economic cooperation and identify features and work systems that may be 
adapted by the PBG;
(ii) proposing  an  institutional  framework  for  PBG  economic  cooperation, 
including  policy-dialogue  mechanisms  (national  leaders',  ministerial,  and 
senior  officials' meetings),  technical  working  groups and sector-specific
committees, and a secretariat, withrespective terms of references; and
(iii) drafting  a  capacity  building  program  that  will  help  implement  and 
operationalize the roadmap.
B. National Consultants (40 person-months)
4. Eleven regional cooperation coordinators (1 from each country with total inputs 
of 40 person-months) will be recruited to assist the international consultants on various 
assignments by researching and compiling government policies and procedures, collecting 
relevant  data,  translating  documents,  and  ensuring  that  the  work  produced  by  the 
international consultants meets regional and national needs. They should also have good 
contacts with the public and private sectors. The national consultants will be supervised by 
the international consultants and by the ADB task manager(s). In particular, the national 
consultants  will  assist  the  PBG  Joint  Expert  Group and  international  consultants in 
preparing the road map for PBG economic cooperation. They will have at least 5 years of 
experience in regional cooperation and excellent understanding of the development issues 
in their respective countries. Specific responsibilities include:
(i) collecting background information required by the international experts and 
PBG Joint Expert Groupmembers in drafting the roadmap; 
(ii) providing  background  research  and  coordination  assistance  to  the 
international experts and PBG Joint Expert Group members;  
(iii) assisting in the review of economic development trends in the PBG countries 
and proposing possible pilot projects that may be implemented within the 
next 5 years;
(iv) liaising  with  national  agencies  to  promote  awareness  on  PBG  economic 
cooperation  and  helping  prepare meetings,  workshops,  seminars,
conferences,and presentation materials and background papers; and
(v) providing other support as required by the ADB task manager(s) and needed 
in the formulation and finalization of the roadmap.
C. Resource Persons (international and national)
5. Resource  persons  may  be  engaged  to  help  prepare,  attend,  or  present  to 
conferences, seminars, and training events organized under this TA project.

ADB – Asian Development Bank
ASEAN – Association of Southeast Asian Nations
CAFTA – China–ASEAN Free Trade Area
GMS – Greater Mekong Subregion
PBG – Pan-Beibu Gulf
PRC – People’s Republic of China
RCI – regional cooperation and integration
TA – technical assistance
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION
Type – Regional—Policy and advisory technical assistance (R-PATA)
Targeting classification – General intervention
Sector (subsectors) – Multisector (trade and service, transport management and policies)
Themes(subthemes) – Economic  growth (promoting  economic efficiency and enabling 
business environment), and regional cooperation and integration 
(trade and investments)
Location (impact) – Rural (medium), urban (medium), regional (high)
NOTE
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.
Vice-President S. Groff, Operations 2
Director General K. Gerhaeusser, East Asia Department (EARD)
